newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada bonds close firmer, outperform U.S. issues.
newsitem.headline: Canada bonds close firmer, outperform U.S. issues.

text.p: Canadian bonds closed firmer on Tuesday, boosted by domestic buying interest in quiet trade, with investors focusing on Wednesday's auction of both Canadian and U.S. bonds, analysts said.

"Generally we've seen buyers, but we've had fairly light activity," said a bond trader at one bank-owned brokerage. "It's just enough to move the market, but nothing decisive. Generally we've seen better domestic buying."
Canada's 30-year bond rose C$0.20 to C$112.05 to yield 6.991 percent. The U.S. 30-year benchmark bond traded unchanged to yield 6.70 percent.
The spread between the benchmark bonds narrowed to 29 basis points from 30 basis points at the close of trading on Monday.

"The U.S. certainly was kept behind by the auctions they had today and also the next couple of days," said David Yu, a fixed-income portfolio manager with Perigee Investment Counsel Inc. "There appear to be some term extension trades today. That would explain why our long end is doing much better today than the U.S."
The U.S. government today held the first of three auctions this week to sell almost US$40 billion in bonds.
While results were fairly good for the first auction this afternoon of US$17.75 billion of three-year bonds, U.S. investors were seen as cautious ahead of the two remaining auctions.
In Canada, the Government of Canada tomorrow will auction C$2.3 billion of 10-year bonds.

In other prices, the Government of Canada's 7.0 percent bond due 2006 rose C$0.17 to C$104.95 to yield 6.313 percent. The U.S. 10-year bond fell 1/32 to yield 6.41 percent. The negative spread between the bonds widened to 10 basis points from eight basis points at Monday's close.
The three-month cash T-bill traded with a yield of 2.86 percent against the U.S. bill which yielded 5.15 percent.
